column2: which is great!! Â Writers deserve all the love they can get. Â Likes

column4: comments
column6: these are the lifeblood of writers. Â They are proof that people are reading
column7: that theyâ€™re enjoying
column8: and that they want more. Â  But maybe readers donâ€™t know what to say. Â Maybe youâ€™re new to Tumblr
column11: or just not sure how to say what you want to say. Let me start by saying
column12: no matter how popular the blog or how cool you think they are
column13: everyone loves a compliment. Â If youâ€™re worried about sounding silly or bothering people
column14: let me assure you- a message will make your writer do a happy dance (depending on the writer
column15: they may actually get up and dance. Â I have.) Hereâ€™s the basic ways of communicating with writers on Tumblr: Likes and kudos- these are great
column16: theyâ€™re the high-fives in this world. Â Theyâ€™re the â€œhey
column18: because they mean exposure. Â More people see the story and that makes us really happy. Â A reblog with a comment is amazing
column19: especially one that entices others to read. Â These make a writerâ€™s day.Comments and messages- these are the thing that keeps us going. Â Most of us have anon turned on- and if we donâ€™t
column20: just let us know you want a private reply. Â (And
column21: if your writer has anon off
column22: it probably means theyâ€™ve been getting hate and deserve extra love.)Recommendations- recs are like coming in to work to find someone baked your favorite cake and left it on your desk. Â Recommendations make your writer feel so loved and valued! So
column24: but what do you actually SAY to writers? Â It doesnâ€™t have to be much or take a lot of time. A simple â€œThis is great/funny/hot!â€ is wonderful. Â ""Best fic Iâ€™ve read this week!â€œ Â ""Funny as hell and cute too.â€ Â ""You have to read this
column25: itâ€™s awesome!â€œ Â ""I canâ€™t wait for more of this.â€ Â ""I hope you keep going!â€œ Â These are great in reblogs and in messages. Even better is specific feedback. Â We love specific feedback
column26: because it tells us what readers liked and what they didnâ€™t. Â Want to influence our next fic? Â Tell us what you liked about this one and I bet you it will keep showing up! Â Specific feedback is just telling the writer what you liked. Â It doesnâ€™t have to be long or complicated
column27: either. Â (But if you write a lot
column28: we will love you so much.) Was there a character you liked? Â Talk about them: Â ""I love how you wrote Xâ€ â€œY was so funny!â€ Â ""OMG I wanted to STRANGLE Q!â€œ Â ""You can really feel Xâ€™s frustration.â€ Â ""Y has so much depth
column29: theyâ€™re a really well-rounded character.â€œ Â ""R says so much with so few words
column30: itâ€™s amazing.â€ What about a part or line you enjoyed? Â ""That bit in the park- LOVE IT.â€œ Â ""I have never read a better description of a cup of tea.â€ Â ""The way you wrote about his fear
column31: that was heartbreaking.â€œ Was there a part that made you feel something? Â Happy
column33: angry? Â ""That last sentence killed me
column34: heâ€™s so broken.â€ Â ""I wanted to jump around when they finally kissed!â€œ Â ""This chapter was so tense
column35: my heart was pounding by the end.â€ Did the characters or plot or setting remind you of your life? Â ""I live in Brussels
column36: thatâ€™s just how that street looks.â€œ Â ""When Y talked about R
column37: I knew exactly how he felt.â€ Â ""You captured that lost
column38: aimless feeling perfectly; Iâ€™ve so been there.â€œ Are there unanswered questions? Â Mention how much you want the answers. Â ""I canâ€™t wait to find out whatâ€™s in the basket!â€ Â ""That was a cliffhanger ending
column39: wow.â€œ Â ""How is she going to explain THAT?â€ Â (some writers are touchy about Â predicting
column41: so stay away from â€œI bet heâ€™ll throw that letter out.â€ or â€œX is clearly coming back.â€) A few closing notes: be enthusiastic if thatâ€™s your style
column44: caps! Â Tell a writer if youâ€™re rereading their work- very little makes us happier than knowing our writing has the staying power for a second
column47: tenth read. Â Did a reread give you a new insight or feeling about the fic? Â Tell us! Â We will be so excited to hear. Â And remember
column48: recommendations are wonderful- putting up a random post tagging your favorite writers or fics youâ€™re enjoying will show the writers that theyâ€™re writing is more than a flash in the opan and theyâ€™ll get some new readers too! We canâ€™t do this writing thing without you guys. Â So thank you so much! Â Without readers
column49: weâ€™re just talking to ourselves. Â We love and appreciate you for reading- but we need to know youâ€™re doing it. Â We need feedback like we need air. Â Donâ€™t let your favorite writers suffocate! :)  Always reblog.  Never scroll past and not reblog. " False text

column1: desiree-rodriguez 160749193145 "2017-05-17 00:16:39 GMT" https://desiree-rodriguez.tumblr.com/post/160749193145/localbadgirl-16-may-romani-day-of-resistance "localbadgirl:  16 May
column2: Romani Day of Resistance. Romani are usually excluded whenever the topic of the Holocaust/WW2 comes up
column3: so itâ€™s not all too surprising that the Romani Day of Resistance is very unknown to the majority. But it should be celebrated and embraced since it representsÂ a change in the way Romani culture and identity appear in public space - where a history of resistance replaces a history of oppression: On 15 May 1944
column4: the underground resistance movement in the Auschwitz
column5: Birkenau concentration camp   BIIe  warned the Roma that the SS guards were planning to round up the nearly 6
column6: 000 Roma and Sinti prisoners and send them to the gas chambers.Â  On the morning of 16 May
column7: the Romani prisoners did not show up for the usual morning roll call and ceased cooperating with the SS guards. The Roma barricaded themselves into their shanties. They had broken into an equipment warehouse and armed themselves with hammers
column8: pickaxes and shovels
column9: taking apart the wooden sections of the bunks they slept on to make wooden stakes.Â  When the SS guards approached the area
column10: they were met with armed resistance from the inmates.Â  The prisoners forced the guards into retreat
column11: and though some prisoners were shot that night
column12: the act of resistance allowed the Roma and Sinti prisoners to put off execution for several more months. The SS were in shock because they had completely failed to anticipate this resistance. Concerned they might lose more men and that the uprising might spread to other parts of Auschwitz
column13: they retreated from camp BIIe. No Roma died in the gas chambers that day. The Nazis subsequently put the prisoners of BIIe on a starvation diet. Later
column15: 500 of the strongest Romani prisoners to Auschwitz I
column16: many of whom were then sent to Buchenwald concentration camp. On 25 May 1944
column17: 82 Romani men were transported to the Flossenburg concentration camp and 144 young Romani women were sent to the RavensbrÃ¼ck concentration camp. Â  Less than 3
column18: 000 Romani prisoners remained in the family camp at BIIe
column19: most of them children. On 2 August 1944
column20: the Nazis gassed all the remaining Romani prisoners to death in gas chamber V
column21: although the Roma fought back on that dark night as well.   In Hungary the 2nd ofÂ August was designated in 2005 by the Parliament as â€œRoma and Sinti Genocide Remembrance Dayâ€
column22: yet most European countries make no or insufficient mention of the Roma victims in their official position regarding the Holocaust.Â    Roma are still misrepresented by stereotypes that overshadow our culture and real identity and it should be needless to say that Europe should put someÂ effort on making the Roma genocide widely known and recognized
column23: to serve as a counterforce to the increasingly violent rhetoric and action against the Roma because and through them. Yet it does not seem like anything like that will happen any time soon.Â  & Yes
column24: please reblog this to make at least some of our history known. " False text

column12: but these are reasons for art to exist that assume you do not give a damn about art. Firstly: fineÂ art creates utility for many other people. Whether or not you find any utility in it yourself
column13: many people in your community do. I do not find sports particularly valuable- I honestly think thereâ€™s not much in the world thatâ€™s more boring than men running around on a field kicking a ball- but most other people seem to for some reason. If the other people in my community want to fund sports
column14: I think they should receive funding even if Iâ€™m individually against it. Because clearly
column15: theyâ€™re getting something out of it. Secondly: Fine art employs a lot of members of the community who would otherwise be unemployable. The tormented artist stereotype has a grain of truth in it: many artists struggle with physical and mental illness. Having a career in art- like many other careers where youâ€™re self-employed- means being able to work at your own pace. Having too many bad days in a row wonâ€™t get you fired. Funding the arts means giving disabled people the time and breathing room they need to begin a career on their own merits
column16: without working themselves to death trying to hold down a more â€˜normalâ€™ job. Â  Thirdly: art gives us a common language we can use to communicate
column17: in the same way that science does. If I say a government policy isÂ â€œOrwellianâ€
column19: you know I meanÂ â€œitâ€™s dictatorialâ€
column20: with the heavy implication that it creates a surveillance state. If I say something is aÂ â€œCinderella storyâ€
column21: you know I mean itâ€™s an underdog story
column22: presumably with a heavy element of rags-to-riches. Art creates connotations and shades of meaning that enrich and deepen human communication. There are as many good reasons to fund art as there are to fund higher maths
column23: honestly. Number theory isnâ€™t immediately useful to anyoneâ€™s life
column24: and yet I donâ€™t think youâ€™d have any problem with the government funding mathematics departments.  I might come across really terrible right now
column25: but how does anyone not understandÂ â€œWe need the arts because they make us full human beings.â€? Is there anyone who listens to no music
column28: plays no games ever?Â   To get more simple
column29: the art of storytelling has existed pretty much forever. Even if we pull out the shit thatâ€™s strictly functional
column31: introduce me to them because Iâ€™m curious about the quality of their lives. It sounds horrible and depressing. MaybeÂ â€œfull human beingsâ€ isnâ€™t quite fair wording
column32: but mental and emotional health is vastly improved by these things and itâ€™s ridiculous to claim that it isnâ€™t. I wonâ€™t say everyone has to create to be at their happiest. I canâ€™t personally process not creating things
column33: but I understand that not everyoneâ€™s into it. (Though I could argue that to some extent things like doodling while bored and humming or whistling are in themselves acts of creation.) But most human beings ever have consumed art
column34: regardless of what kind. It is a very important part of most peopleâ€™s lives. " False link

column2: the Ava DuVernay drama unveiled its lineup of all-female directors for the upcoming season as well as a return date.     OWN and producer Warner Bros. Television also announced a new deal with Hulu that will make the streamer the exclusive SVOD home for Queen Sugar. The first season will be available to stream beginning April 21st.   Like season one
column3: season two will feature an all-female directing team that includes returning producer-director Kat Chandler
column4: DeMane Davis (Lift)
column6: Aurora Guerrero (Mosquita y Mari) and Amanda Marsalis (Echo Park)
column7: who will make her episodic television debut on Queen Sugar.     The rest of the directing team for Queen Sugarâ€™s sixteen-episode second season
column8: which launches with a two-night event on June 20th and 21st at 10 p.m
column9: will be announced at a later date.     Queen Sugar was one of the first TV dramas to assemble an all-female directing team. The decision came in the wake of troubling statistics from the Directors Guild of America and other organizations about the lack of female and minority directors in television despite the current Peak TV era that has born more than 400 original scripted series. During the 2014-15 TV season
column10: only 16 percent of TV directors were females.    Since then
column11: several others in Hollywood have also made it their mission to increase the number of females and minorities behind the camera. Prolific producer and director Ryan Murphy launched the Half foundation to ensure that half of all the episodes of television he produces are directed by females and minorities. Huluâ€™s period drama Harlots
column12: which launched last month on the streamer
column13: assembled an all-female directing team as well as an all-female writerâ€™s room. â€œForward-thinking people and allies of this cause within the industry have the common sense to know that this is systemic

column2: once again
column3: Arrow fails.The show never seemed to fully understand the concept of the Black Canary. Dinah Laurel Lance is ultimately her own separate character apart from Green Arrow and Oliver Queen. The show should have worked harder to establish her as a separate character from the get-go instead of a spurned lover Oliver cheated on. There were shades of the comics Dinah Lance in Arrowâ€™s depiction
column4: and there was the clear signs of a narrative journey being taken towards her becoming the Black Canary. However it became clear by the time season three rolled around the show lost interest. Forgot who the Black Canary was â€“ more than a leather jacket
column5: motorcycle riding woman with a sharp tongue and a sonic cry â€“ and why she was important. Laurel as such suffered as a character. Reduced to a rushed short term story arc
column6: quickly pushed further and further aside
column7: and lost more narrative relevance. Until finally the show decided to just up and kill the Black Canary
column8: a longterm important character within the DC Universe and an important part of the overall narrative of Arrow itself.While Laurel lost screentime
column9: her overall presence was still relative to the story at hand. She existed as a central figure within the overall fabric of the narrative having ties and history with Oliver
column15: and Tommy. Â Viewers could see this in Arrowâ€™s 100th episode which emphasized how central Laurel and Oliver once were to the showâ€™s narrative.Now thereâ€™s little reason for Lance to even exist on the show given that his storyline is a circular tragedy of losing one daughter to gain another to lose another and end in and out of rehabs. Thea lost a sister figure and her own screentime has gone down dramatic. Oliver lost a close childhood friend
column16: and a huge part of his past (namely the first two seasons) as well as his canonical comic longterm partner.So the misstep is two-fold; the show purposely cast aside one of the long standing characters that originally had an on-going and solid arc to explore and develop
column17: and an iconic comic book character. This isnâ€™t such a problem that can be fixed with the insertion of a new character that happens to also have the name Dinah Drake. Which appears to be the most popular name in Star City.â€" True link
